A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {M : Type u_4} [inst : AddCommMonoid M] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop M},
  (Finset.sum s fun i => f i) = ⊤ ↔ ∃ i ∈ s, f i = ⊤
name: WithTop.sum_eq_top_iff
docString: A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString: This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

If `x` is a Liouville number, then for each natural number `n`, there exist infinitely many natural number denominators `b` and an integer numerator `a` such that `|x - a/b| < 1/b^n`.

type: ∀ {x : ℝ}, Liouville x → ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (b : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, ∃ a, x ≠ ↑a / ↑b ∧ |x - ↑a / ↑b| < 1 / ↑b ^ n
statement:
theorem Liouville.frequently_exists_num :
    ∀ {x : ℝ}, Liouville x → ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (b : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, ∃ a, x ≠ ↑a / ↑b ∧ |x - ↑a / ↑b| < 1 / ↑b ^ n := by
  sorry
name: Liouville.frequently_exists_num
docString:
If `x` is a Liouville number, then for any `n`, for infinitely many denominators `b` there
exists a numerator `a` such that `x ≠ a / b` and `|x - a / b| < 1 / b ^ n`.
description: The theorem `Liouville.frequently_exists_num` asserts that if `x` is a Liouville number, then for any natural number `n`, there are infinitely many natural number denominators `b` for which there exists an integer numerator `a` such that `x` is not equal to `a / b` and the absolute value of the difference between `x` and `a / b` is less than `1 / b^n`. Here, the phrase "infinitely many" is mathematically represented by `Filter.atTop`, which denotes a condition that holds true for sufficiently large values.
concise-description: If `x` is a Liouville number, then for each natural number `n`, there exist infinitely many natural number denominators `b` and an integer numerator `a` such that `|x - a/b| < 1/b^n`.

Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

type: (s : Set ℕ) → [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ s] → [inst : Infinite ↑s] → Denumerable ↑s
name: Nat.Subtype.denumerable
docString: Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

For any infinite set of natural numbers and any positive natural number, there exist distinct elements with the same remainder when divided by that number.

type: ∀ {s : Set ℕ}, s.Infinite → ∀ {k : ℕ}, 0 < k → ∃ m ∈ s, ∃ n ∈ s, m < n ∧ k.ModEq m n
name: Nat.exists_lt_modEq_of_infinite
docString: For any infinite set of natural numbers and any positive natural number, there exist distinct elements with the same remainder when divided by that number.

This theorem states that for any real number 'a', the cardinality (or size) of the interval from negative infinity to 'a' (inclusive) is equal to the cardinality of the continuum. In other words, the set of all real numbers less than or equal to 'a' has the same number of elements as the set of all real numbers. This is consistent with the concept in mathematics that there are the same amount of numbers between any two different real numbers as there are real numbers in total, implying the idea of infinity in the real number line.

name: Cardinal.mk_Iic_real
docString: This theorem states that for any real number 'a', the cardinality (or size) of the interval from negative infinity to 'a' (inclusive) is equal to the cardinality of the continuum. In other words, the set of all real numbers less than or equal to 'a' has the same number of elements as the set of all real numbers. This is consistent with the concept in mathematics that there are the same amount of numbers between any two different real numbers as there are real numbers in total, implying the idea of infinity in the real number line.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {M : Matroid α} [self : Matroid.InfiniteRk M], ∃ B, M.Base B ∧ Set.Infinite B
name: Matroid.InfiniteRk.exists_infinite_base

The set of prime numbers is unbounded.

name: Nat.not_bddAbove_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime numbers is unbounded.

This theorem states that Aleph-zero (ℵ₀), which is known as the smallest infinite cardinal number or the cardinality of the set of natural numbers, is greater than zero. In the context of set theory, it establishes that the size of the set of natural numbers is not empty, but rather infinitely countable, and hence larger than zero.

name: Cardinal.aleph0_pos
docString: This theorem states that Aleph-zero (ℵ₀), which is known as the smallest infinite cardinal number or the cardinality of the set of natural numbers, is greater than zero. In the context of set theory, it establishes that the size of the set of natural numbers is not empty, but rather infinitely countable, and hence larger than zero.

A sum of finite numbers is still finite

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {s : Finset α} {f : α → ENNReal}, (∀ a ∈ s, f a ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.sum s fun a => f a) < ⊤
name: ENNReal.sum_lt_top
docString: A sum of finite numbers is still finite

For every finite set of natural numbers, there exists a natural number that is an upper bound for the set.

type: ∀ (s : Finset ℕ), ∃ n, s ⊆ Finset.range n
name: Finset.exists_nat_subset_range
docString: For every finite set of natural numbers, there exists a natural number that is an upper bound for the set.

**Non-Denumerability of the Continuum Theorem**: This theorem states that the set of all real numbers is uncountable. In other words, there is no one-to-one correspondence (or bijection) between the set of all real numbers and the set of all natural numbers, implying that the cardinality of the real numbers is strictly greater than the cardinality of the natural numbers. This result is a fundamental aspect of set theory and real analysis.

name: Cardinal.not_countable_real
docString: **Non-Denumerability of the Continuum Theorem**: This theorem states that the set of all real numbers is uncountable. In other words, there is no one-to-one correspondence (or bijection) between the set of all real numbers and the set of all natural numbers, implying that the cardinality of the real numbers is strictly greater than the cardinality of the natural numbers. This result is a fundamental aspect of set theory and real analysis.

A product of finite numbers is still finite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {R : Type u_8} [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] [inst_1 : NoZeroDivisors R] [inst_2 : Nontrivial R]
  [inst_3 : DecidableEq R] [inst_4 : LT R] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop R},
  (∀ i ∈ s, f i ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.prod s fun i => f i) < ⊤
name: WithTop.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite

There are finitely many subsets of a given finite set

type: ∀ {α : Type u} {a : Set α}, Set.Finite a → Set.Finite {b | b ⊆ a}
name: Set.Finite.finite_subsets
docString: There are finitely many subsets of a given finite set

Type of natural numbers with infinity (`⊤`)

name: PartENat
docString: Type of natural numbers with infinity (`⊤`)

Infinite ordinals that are cardinals are unbounded.

type: Set.Unbounded (fun x x_1 => x < x_1) {b | Cardinal.ord (Ordinal.card b) = b ∧ Ordinal.omega ≤ b}
name: Cardinal.ord_card_unbounded'
docString: Infinite ordinals that are cardinals are unbounded.
